did.abstract: Democratic member of the Ann Arbor City Council (Mich.); also member of the Ann Arbor Planning Commission, the Ann Arbor Development Authority, and the Huron River Watershed Council. The collection includes correspondence, reports, minutes, and other materials largely concerning her organizational activities.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Eunice L. Burns (Donor No. 4738) in multiple accessions beginning in 1979.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Bentley Historical Library.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Eunice Burns papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Eunice L. Burns has been active in Ann Arbor civic and community affairs and city politics since the mid-1950s. For more than four decades, she has been a keen observer and sometime participant in Ann Arbor city government. Beginning first with her involvement in the revision of Ann Arbor's city charter in 1955, Burns went on in local politics with her successful campaign in 1962 for a seat on the Ann Arbor City Council. While on council, Burns's principal interests were in the areas of civil rights and city planning. She was a strong advocate for the landmark Ann Arbor Fair Housing Ordinance which was enacted on September 16, 1963.

Burns was re-elected to her council seat in 1964 and again in 1966. In 1965, in the midst of her second term on council, Burns decided to run for mayor. Hoping to be the first woman mayor and the first Democratic mayor elected since 1957, Burns lost to incumbent Republican Wendell Hulcher by more than three thousand votes. Despite her defeat, she continued to represent the first ward on council for another three years. In 1968, she decided against running for a fourth term, choosing instead to become a member of the Ann Arbor Planning Commission. She served on the commission until June 1974, serving as chair of the commission from May 1970 to August 1971.

Before coming to Ann Arbor, Burns had received her BS degree from Wisconsin State College and had done graduate work at the University of Wisconsin and New York University. In 1967, she began pursuing her Master's degree in the political science department at the University of Michigan. Specializing in urban planning, she received her Master's in 1970. Burns became Assistant Dean of the School of Education at the University of Michigan in the 1970s. When, in 1973, Marcia Federbush filed a complaint with the University of Michigan Athletic Department listing 125 instances where women athletes were treated unfairly, Burns was asked by U-M President Robben Fleming to chair the Committee for Study of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women. Burns, with the rest of the committee, did a survey of programs at other large universities, collected testimony from Michigan women athletes, and issued a report.
In 1980, Burns was elected vice-chair of the Huron Watershed Council. She has also been active in Ann Arbor's Downtown Development Authority (DDA) since 1979.

scopecontent.p: The Eunice L. Burns collection primarily documents her activities in Ann Arbor government. The collection has been divided into five series: Ann Arbor City Council, 1962-68; Ann Arbor Planning Commission, 1968-74, University of Michigan Committee to Study Intercollegiate Athletics for Women, 1971-76; Downtown Development Authority, 1979-90; Huron River Watershed Council; and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.p: Ann Arbor City Council, the largest series in the collection, concerns municipal government issues during the turbulent 1960s in addition to some material in the 1970s and 1980s as well. Of greatest significance perhaps was the city-wide debate over a fair housing ordinance. Burns's involvement in this issue is documented in this series as well as the involvement of citizens and groups such as CORE and the NAACP. Civil rights issues are also addressed in the following folders: Police, Human Rights, and the Human Relations Committee. Other issues documented in this series include Ann Arbor's physical growth and such related areas as water, parking, and the maintenance and improvement of various public services. Furthermore, information on candidates and election returns, materials handed out to precinct workers, and mayoral campaign material and speeches are included.

did.unittitle: Commercial Development and Zoning Statistics (Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti Area) 1963
Parks: Swimming Pools and Skating Rinks 1966-1967
Shelter Program Protest Letter to President Kennedy circa 1963
Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (Ann Arbor-Ypsilanti Branch) 1963

scopecontent.p: The Ann Arbor Planning Commission series documents the activities of Burns as chairman and member of the planning commission and relates to physical changes proposed for the city.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor Public Schools: Building/Site Issues 1974
Isberg-Courtelis-Abbott Zoning Petition (Black Pond Development Dispute) 1968
Letters to the Editor (Ann Arbor News), 1970
University Of Michigan Committee to Study Intercollegiate Sports for Women 1970-1976

scopecontent.p: In 1973 Burns was asked to chair the University of Michigan Committee to Study Intercollegiate Sports for Women. Files from this work include memos and correspondence, minutes of meetings and a report of the committee.

did.unittitle: State of Michigan Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women 1973-1976

scopecontent.p: Act 197 of the Public Acts of 1975 provides for the establishment of Downtown Development Authorities. DDAs have the purpose to assist in the restoration of downtown districts of communities. Burns's involvement in the DDA is documented in this series.

did.unittitle: Report to the Michigan Legislature March 31, 1979

scopecontent.p: The Huron River Watershed Council files largely documents the annual Huron River Day celebration. There are also published and collected materials relating to the protection of the Huron River Watershed.

did.unittitle: State of the Huron Conference 2003, 2005, and 2008
Board of Directors / Executive Committee materials 1993-2011

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous series concerns Burns's activities with the Ann Arbor Democratic Committee. There are also articles and speeches and papers she wrote while studying for his master's degree in politics science at the University of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Master's Papers and Projects (in Political Science at The University of Michigan) 1967-1970
